pr_title: PR for 13576: NLS messages and metatype properties

timeline.message: Issue 13576: Metatype descriptions and NLS messages

timeline.bodyText:
Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication
what does "it" refer to in this context?
timeline.author: dmuelle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -106,4 +106,19 @@ elapsedNBF.desc=Identifies the elapsed time until JWT will start to be accepted
 
 #Do not translate "amr"
 amrValues=Authentication methods references in string array
-amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
\ No newline at end of file
+amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.

replies.bodyText: I'm actually not entirely sure - that property was written and delivered elsewhere. Best guess from the context is that "it" would be our JWT consumer functionality.
replies.author: ayoho

replies.bodyText:
capitalization of "Authentication Methods References" should be consistent in the name and description-
Authentication Methods References in string array

suggested edit
Specifies Authentication Methods References (amr) to enforce step-up authentication and indicate how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values.
replies.author: dmuelle

replies.bodyText: There's a bit of a catch-22 in our metatype properties validation when it comes to proper names and acronyms. The name is required to be in sentence case (unless a specific exception is made for individual words) while the description is a bit more relaxed. If I wanted to put "International Business Machines" in the name, for instance, by default it would have to be "International business machines" to comply with the validation rules even though that's not actually proper. In any case, I don't think anything is lost with lowercasing the phrase in the description so I've gone ahead and done that.
replies.author: ayoho

timeline.bodyText:
change
...the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.
to
...the content encryption Key of a JWE.
timeline.author: dmuelle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -106,4 +106,19 @@ elapsedNBF.desc=Identifies the elapsed time until JWT will start to be accepted
 
 #Do not translate "amr"
 amrValues=Authentication methods references in string array
-amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
\ No newline at end of file
+amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
+
+# Do not translate "Content Encryption Key"
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm=Key management key algorithm
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm.desc=Specifies the encryption algorithm that is used to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.

replies.bodyText: "Content Encryption Key" is a term defined in the JWE specification that we're implementing here (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7516#section-2); the whole phrase is a specific term that refers to a well-defined object.
replies.author: ayoho

timeline.bodyText:
change
Content Encryption
to
content encryption
timeline.author: dmuelle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -106,4 +106,19 @@ elapsedNBF.desc=Identifies the elapsed time until JWT will start to be accepted
 
 #Do not translate "amr"
 amrValues=Authentication methods references in string array
-amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
\ No newline at end of file
+amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
+
+# Do not translate "Content Encryption Key"
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm=Key management key algorithm
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm.desc=Specifies the encryption algorithm that is used to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.
+
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm.RSA-OAEP=Use the RSAES OAEP algorithm to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.

timeline.author: dmuelle
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -106,4 +106,19 @@ elapsedNBF.desc=Identifies the elapsed time until JWT will start to be accepted
 
 #Do not translate "amr"
 amrValues=Authentication methods references in string array
-amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
\ No newline at end of file
+amrValues.desc= Specifies Authentication Methods References so it can enforce step-up authentication and know how the user is authenticated. Specify a comma separated list of valid amr claim values to be used.
+
+# Do not translate "Content Encryption Key"
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm=Key management key algorithm
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm.desc=Specifies the encryption algorithm that is used to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.
+
+keyManagementKeyAlgorithm.RSA-OAEP=Use the RSAES OAEP algorithm to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.
+
+keyManagementKeyAlias=Key management key alias
+keyManagementKeyAlias.desc=Public key alias of the Key Management Key that is used to encrypt the Content Encryption Key of a JWE.

replies.bodyText:
Should this be Key Management Mode? I see "Key Management Mode" defined in the spec but not Key Management Key. (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7516#section-2)
If it should remain Key Management Key- the capitalization  should be consistent between the name and description
replies.author: dmuelle

replies.bodyText: I decided to lowercase the phrase since it doesn't refer to a well-defined concept from the spec.
replies.author: ayoho
